poem:
**Shania at Glastonbury**

Out of the whispers,
through fields quilted in denim patches,
she arrives,
not on horseback but on rhythm,
singing the dawn pink,
trailing stardust in her wake—
a constellation in cowboy boots,
inviting the world
to sway,
under a sky stitched
with music and myth.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Shania Twain at Glastonbury review – country-pop legend doesn’t hold her horses Long before Shania Twain’s set on the Pyramid stage, there were signs of building anticipation in the double denim and cowboy hats – either brought from home or quickly acquired from the stalls so as to feel part of the fun. The whispers going around Worthy farm was that Twain would arrive on stage riding a horse. As often the case with Glastonbury". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
